TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in PERSON . The facts of the case are disputed by the parties . Their respective accounts may be summarised as follows .

CARDINAL . The applicant submitted that at TIME on DATE she and her sister were stopped on the street by a police officer ( “ ORG ” ) who ordered them to accompany him to FAC . When they refused to comply with ORG ’s request , he forcibly took them to the police station and , according to the applicant , at CARDINAL point he pushed her while she was on a flight of stairs at the police station . The applicant submitted that while she was at the police station she was beaten severely by CARDINAL drunk men in plain clothes . In particular , she claimed that the QUANTITY men pushed her from her chair , hit her head against a steam radiator , tried to strangle her and punched and kicked her in the head and body . She claimed that all these acts took place in the presence of police officers . The applicant and her sister were later driven to FAC and held in custody until she was brought before a judge the following TIME . During this period she was not examined by a doctor .

CARDINAL . The Government contested the applicant ’s account of the events surrounding her arrest on DATE . In doing so they relied on statements provided by ORG , the applicant ’s brother - in - law , another police officer ( “ R ” ) , and a civilian who was present at the police station when the applicant arrived . The Government submitted that on TIME DATE the applicant had been celebrating her birthday at her sister ’s home . She got into a physical fight with her sister ’s husband . It is not clear from the statements whether the applicant ’s brother - in - law went to the police station to report the applicant ’s behaviour or whether ORG was walking past the applicant ’s sister ’s home when he noticed the fighting . Nevertheless , the statements of ORG and the applicant ’s brother - in - law both indicated that when ORG arrived at the scene , the applicant was assaulting her brother - in - law and would not calm down . In particular , the applicant ’s brother - in - law told the prosecutor that the applicant had pushed him to the ground and was hitting him with her fists .

CARDINAL . ORG confirmed in his statement to the prosecutor that when he arrived at the scene the applicant insulted him and her brother - in - law . After he cautioned her , she began to hit and kick her brother - in - law . The applicant ’s brother - in - law also stated that :

“ Tanea [ the applicant ] picked a fight with ORG and was pulling his epaulettes with a view to tearing them off , called him “ a rotten cop ” , told him that she was living with a former prisoner and that he would eliminate him . ”

CARDINAL . AC therefore asked the applicant , her sister and her brother - in - law to accompany him to the station . In his statement to the prosecutor he conceded that he had to use some force to bring the applicant there . In his evidence given to ORG he stated that he grabbed the applicant by the hand but did not use any other form of physical force . At the police station the applicant continued to be aggressive towards ORG . The applicant ’s brother - in law stated that :
“ At the police station , PERSON and the sister in law PERSON were continuing to make noise , calling the policemen “ rotten cops ” and other explicit words . ”
CARDINAL . A civilian who happened to be at the police station when the applicant , her sister and her sister ’s husband arrived , stated that :
“ The people [ the police officer ] brought with him were inebriated , were shouting , insulting the policeman , pulling him by his clothes and threatening him with being fired from the police . ”
CARDINAL . None of the witnesses indicate that the applicant had any visible injuries when she arrived at the police station .

CARDINAL . The Government stated that after the police officer had drawn up a report documenting the applicant ’s misdemeanour , she was transported to a public drugs clinic so that her blood alcohol level could be tested . The ORG submitted a report from the clinic which confirmed that the applicant was intoxicated .

On DATE the prosecutor informed the applicant that ORG had acted in accordance with the law and that her complaint had been dismissed on DATE on the ground that there was a lack of “ constitutive elements ” of an offence .

She stated , inter alia , that the prosecutor had omitted to examine the ORG statements which had been enclosed with the case file and the medical report of DATE . The applicant also submitted that she had been beaten by ORG , R and another police officer ( “ C ” ) and that her ill - treatment had been witnessed by her nephew ( “ N ” ) and CARDINAL other women ( “ OC ” and “ RC ” ) .

CARDINAL . ORG considered the applicant ’s submissions at an oral hearing . In the course of the hearing the applicant , her sister , and ORG gave oral evidence . In her evidence to the court , the applicant ’s sister stated that both she and the applicant had been beaten by CARDINAL unknown men in plain clothes and that the events had been witnessed by police officers and by her son , N.
